Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Discontinuous Shear Thickening and Shear Jamming in Dense Suspensions: Statistical Mechanics and the Microscopic Basis for Extreme Transitions of Properties

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET - 1605283/1605428
PI: Morris, Jeffrey F./Chakraborty, Bulbul

This collaborative project comprises computational and theoretical studies of the flow of suspensions consisting of solid particles in liquids. The project focuses on concentrated suspensions, where particles occupy more than half of the mixture volume. These are often called dense suspensions, and they are found in application as cement, concrete, and mineral ore slurries. Dense suspensions can change properties suddenly when flow conditions change. In some cases, as the strength of the flow, or shear rate, increases, the mixture can suddenly exhibit an extremely large increase in flow resistance, a phenomenon known as "discontinuous shear thickening" (DST). The flow can even stop, which is known as "shear jamming." DST can have major negative effects on industrial processes involving the mixtures. While DST has been known for many years, it has not been explained. The goal of this project is to determine why this phenomenon happens, which could provide guidance how to design suspensions and processing operations to diminish negative effects of DST. Results of the research will be used in modules that will enable high school students to visualize how many-particle systems result in large-scale behavior, such as DST in cornstarch suspensions, where small grains of starch cause enormous changes in flow properties.

The project will explore recent observations that DST can be explained by particle contacts and friction. The work will explore the structure of networks of forces between the particles and how this structure changes as the flow rate is increased to a level causing abrupt changes in properties. In particular, the team will explore whether the flow property transition has the characteristics of a phase transition through simulations of discrete particles in different flows and applications of theoretical concepts from statistical physics. The role of the liquid will be considered by comparing results with the behavior of dry granular systems in which the force network concept and its relation to jamming have been examined by others. This work will probe the relationship of flow-induced property changes to thermodynamic phase transitions and will establish the similarities and differences between different particulate flows. Because solid-liquid mixtures are commonly used in industry and are found in geophysical settings such as mud flows, the project will significantly expand our ability to understand and ultimately predict the dynamics of these complicated systems in important applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project led by PIs J. Morris of CCNY and B. Chakraborty of Brandeis has generated novel understanding of dense suspension flow phenomena discontinuous shear thickening and shear jamming, published in journal papers.  The project has also been instrumental in establishment of a much stronger community of scientists engaged in the study of dense suspension flows.  The latter is evidenced by two workshops organized by the PIs, one a week-long affair at Georgetown University in 2016 with Chakraborty a co-organizer, and a major January-April 2018 workshop on Physics of Dense Suspensions at the Kavi Institute at UC Santa Barbara, for which the PIs were both organizers along with E. Del Gado of Georgetown University and W. Poon of University of Edinburgh (UK).

 

The papers from CCNY, including collaborative work with the Brandeis team, are:

 R. Seto, A. Singh, B. Chakraborty, M. M. Denn & J. F. Morris 2019 Shear jamming and fragility in dense suspensions. Granular Matter 21, paper 82. https://doi.org/10.1007/s10035-019-0931-5

 

M. Gameiro, A. Singh, L. Kondic, K. Mischaikow & J. F. Morris 2019 Interaction network analysis in shear thickening suspensions. To appear in Phys. Rev. Fluids.

 

O. Sedes. A. Singh & J. F. Morris 2019 Critical point analysis in discontinuous shear thickening of a dense suspension. Submitted to J. Rheology.

 

A. Singh, S. Pednekar, J. Chun, M. M. Denn & J. F. Morris 2018 From yielding to jamming in a cohesive frictional suspension.  Phys. Rev. Letters 122, 098004.

 

 L. E. Edens, S. Pednekar, J. F. Morris, G. K. Schenter, A. E. Clark & J. Chun 2019 Global topology of contact force networks: new insight into shear thickening suspensions. Phys Rev. E. 99, 012607.

 

J. F. Morris 2018 The lubricated-to-frictional shear thickening scenario in dense suspensions.  (Invited). Phys. Rev. Fluids. 3, 110508.


 J. F. Morris 2020 Shear thickening of concentrated suspensions: recent developments and related phenomena. .  In press. Ann. Rev. Fluid Mech. V. 52

 

J. Thomas, K. Ramola, A. Singh, R. Mari, J. F. Morris & B. Chakraborty 2018 Microscopic origin of frictional rheology in dense suspensions: correlations in force space.  Phys. Rev. Lett. 121, 128002.

 

A major new effort seen in the Edens work (with a PNNL/Washington State team) and the Gameiro work (with an NJIT/Rutgers team) is the application of topological invariant methods to extract understanding on the force networks emphasized in this project.  The PIs are now collaborating with another CCNY researcher (H. Makse) on methods to apply statistical methods to the understanding of the network structures found in suspension flows.

 

Finally, the work has led to clear recognition of this team as a leader in the field, as Morris has been appointed lead guest editor on a special issue of the Journal of Rheology devoted to the Physics of Dense Suspensions with co-editor E. Del Gado of Georgetown University. This issue will capture developments associated with the recent surge of activity in this field.
